H0.text: The nitrogen gas in box A has a greater mass than the nitrogen gas in box B, even though both boxes contain the same number of nitrogen molecules and the molecules in box A move twice as fast as those in box B.

H1.text: The nitrogen gas in box A has a greater density than the nitrogen gas in box B, even though both boxes contain the same number of nitrogen gas molecules and the molecules in box A move at twice the average speed of those in box B.

H2.text: The nitrogen gas in box A has a greater temperature than the nitrogen gas in box B, because the same number of nitrogen molecules in box A move at twice the average speed of those in box B.

H3.text: The nitrogen gas in box A has a greater specific gravity than the nitrogen gas in box B, because the molecules in box A have twice the average speed of those in box B while both boxes contain the same number of nitrogen molecules.

A4.text: The average translational kinetic energy per molecule is directly proportional to the absolute temperature, as shown by the equation $\\frac{1}{2}mv^2 = \\frac{3}{2}k_B T$.
